Welcome to the Facebook voting portion of the Naughty or Nice Cookie Challenge presented by the Honest Weight Food Co-op and the Times Union. 

PLEASE NOTE VOTING HAS CLOSED AS OF 2 P.M. NOV. 18.
Totals were: Amazon (15); Cranberry orange (181); Jamtastic (45); Nanny's (14); Jalapeno (54); Peppercorn (57).

One winner will be selected from each division after online votes and People's Choice votes are totaled.

People's Choice voting (where you can taste samples of the entries) will be held from 1 to 3 p.m. Dec. 3 at Honest Weight, 100 Watervliet Ave, Albany.

We'll announce the winner in the Times Union food section and at timesunion.com on Dec. 8. The winner in each division receives a prize package from Honest Weight and will have their cookie recipe baked and sold at the store during the holiday season.

It's time to vote for your favorite photo among our 10 finalists in the #518daytrip contest.
To vote, simply like the photo you want to win. (And feel free to share on Facebook to encourage votes). The entry with the most likes by noon on Sept. 1 wins the Autumn Harvest package courtesy of Cooperstown's Otesaga Resort Hotel (includes an overnight stay for two and is valued at more than $400). The winner will also have their photo published in the Albany Times Union and 518Life Magazine.

status_message:
We are looking for great teachers - the good, kind, inspiring, patient, creative teachers that every student hopes to get and every parent is thrilled to see. 

If you know of a teacher like that — maybe you were in their class or your child was — tell us about them in 100 words or fewer. Include the teacher's name, position, school and school district. 

The nominee must be currently teaching in the Capital Region. Please include a picture of the teacher if possible. We will choose five teachers to feature in the paper. Send submissions to Leigh Hornbeck at lhornbeck@timesunion.com. Questions? Call Leigh at 454-5352. The deadline is Wednesday, Aug. 24.

status_message: It's been 13 years since Hopewell Junction resident Debra Hall was told by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency that her water was contaminated with something called TCE, or trichloroethylene. After years of meetings, conferences, letters and phone calls, Hall and her neighbors continue to live with water- and air-filtration systems to keep them safe.

status_message:
100 years ago, this eagle-eyed police officer wasn't afraid to ruffle some feathers. 
From the Sept. 19, 1914 headlines of the Times-Union: Officer Cheeseman of the Albany police arrested Adam Goetz on Western Avenue with a large bag full of chickens that he claimed he and another man bought legally in the Bethlehem hamlet of Hurstville. Not believing the man's story, Officer Cheeseman took Goetz to Delmar for arraignment. Wonder if he said, "Quit your squawkin' and come with me."

status_message: Erik Schlimmer is a "reverse retiree." He used his 20s and 30s to explore, then settled into a regular working life when he hit 40. The former Army paratrooper's "retirement" might look like a lot of work to you: He climbed 1,500 peaks, hiked more than 10,000 miles, biked 10,000 miles and spent more than 1,000 nights outside. He biked 2,750 miles from Canada to Mexico. He now has a job working with veterans. -- Mike G.
link_name: 'Reverse retiree' finds adventure in Adirondacks

status_message:
Update: North Colonie's school district says a shelter in place in response to a threat at Shaker High has been lifted. Colonie police conducted a "thorough sweep" of the building and the  school returned to normal operation. Police will stay at the school and continue their investigation, the district's website says. 
Here's the rest of the district's response:
"The threat was made in the Taft Hall C wing boys' bathroom and reported by a student. The threat said, "I'm going to bomb Shaker on 6/14/14 Watch." Due to the lack of specificity, the shelter in place mode was chosen. This is a method that has been developed in conjunction with the Colonie PD and is part of our district emergency response plan. Had the bomb threat been more specific, evacuation or student relocation would have occurred."
Update: the runaway dog is still on the run, last seen heading toward the Niskayuna side of the Mohawk River. (Will Waldron photo) -- Teresa

status_message:
CORRECTION FROM EARLIER POST. The Schoharie man who died pulled into a friend's driveway and said he would be sleeping in his own car. An updated version of the story should be posting soon. :

A 35-year-old man was found dead in his car Sunday morning after asking someone he knew if he could pull into their driveway and sleep overnight.
Schoharie County Sheriff Tony Desmond said that the man, whose identity is not being released, asked someone at a Village of Schoharie residence if he could park his car in the driveway and sleep in it late Saturday night.
When a person exited the residence to check on the man around 11:45 a.m. Sunday, he was dead, Desmond said.

link_name: Trooper revives Columbia County woman

status_message:

status_message:
Bailey Wind didn't think she'd dive competitively again after the Northway crash caused by Dennis Drue killed her boyfriend, a friend and left her and another teen gravely injured. 

"My mom said Dennis Drue took most of my life away from me," Wind said, her voice cracking. "And she wasn't going to let him take diving away. I just worked so hard for it, and I just had it all taken away. It's so hard getting back to that point. It's really frustrating. Extremely frustrating." -- Mike G.
link_name: A year after crash, survivor finds strength from memories

status_message:
The Shaker and Shenendehowa schools plan a "Remembrance Day" on Tuesday as a way to remember the deaths of Shen students Chris Stewart and Deanna Rivers in the Dec. 1, 2012, Northway crash that also badly injured Shaker student Bailey Wind and Shen student Matt Hardy.
According to the North Colonie school district, Shaker High School students, faculty and staff are being encouraged to wear green in a show of unity with Shenendehowa, while Shen students will wear blue to show solidarity with Shaker. -- Tim B.

U.S. Army Sgt. 1st Class Daniel Petithory's grass is at the bottom of a slightly sloping hill in a cemetery in Cheshire, Mass., snug inside the Berkshire mountains. A small wooden cross, surrounded by a half-dozen or so tiny American flags and a Green Beret teddy bear in a secure plastic bag, among other paraphernalia, mark the place of burial for one of the early, and still one of the relatively few, American casualties of the war in Afghanistan.


This is where the kid who joined the service right out of the local high school 15 years ago, just as he vowed, has come home at age 32.
link_name: Times Union - Albany NY

Albino hedgehog alert:

A visitor holds an albino hedgehog in a private zoo in Moscow, Russia, Thursday, Aug. 22, 2013. Three rare albino hedgehog babies, born on the same day as Britain's new prince, have moved into a miniature castle at a Moscow petting zoo. The three are named after the Prince of Cambridge — George, Alexander and Louis. (AP Photo/Alexander Zemlianichenko Jr)

status_message:
In case you missed it in Sunday's paper, Colonie Republican Jennifer Whalen is running for the county clerk's seat being vacated by 25-year incumbent Democrat Tom Clingan, writes Jordan Carleo-Evangelist.

Whalen — who's twice run for Assembly in the old 109th and new 110th Assembly District, nearly toppling Democratic Assemblyman Bob Reilly the first time — plans to run on the premise that being clerk amounts more than being a "potted plant" and filing documents.

Do you think this is a good move? (Select answers may appear in the print edition). --Kristi
link_name: From Sunday: Jennifer Whalen to run for Albany County Clerk

status_message:
A nun as a priest? Perhaps. --Kristi 

Mary Theresa Streck has lived a life according to the principles of her Roman Catholic faith.

For 18 years, she was a nun in the order of Sisters of St. Joseph. While living in the Taylor Apartments in Troy, ministering to its low-income residents, she asked to be let out of her vows to marry Jay Murnane, who was released from his service as a priest.
link_name: Former nun has priesthood plans

status_message: Hey moms! Overwhelmed by work and demands of family life?  Looking for balance? Attend our next Women@Work event, The Mother Load, on Thursday, June 6. Come to this special Women@Work breakfast event and leave with tips you can use to manage life's many demands. This free event is from 7:15-9 a.m. at The Desmond, 660 Albany-Shaker Road, Albany. Moderator Kathleen Crowley, a professor of psychology from The College of St. Rose, will share her expertise and thoughts on how to better manage the work and family life balancing act followed by table break-out discussions and then q&a with the panelists, working moms from sponsor McNamee, Lochner, Titus & Williams, P.C.  Space is limited, register at
link_name: Women@Work: The Mother Load

Two explosions shattered the euphoria of the Boston Marathon finish line on Monday, sending authorities out on the course to carry off the injured while the stragglers in the 26.2-mile trek from Hopkinton were rerouted away from the smoking site of the blasts.

Competitors and race organizers were crying as they fled the chaos. Bloody spectators were being carried to the medical tent that had been set up to care for fatigued runners.

A baseball-bat-wielding Saratoga Springs man allegedly busted his way through a home Thursday, terrorizing the residents before drunkenly crashing his car on East Side Drive, deputies said.

Armed with the bat, Derek C. Rhodes, 32, of 558 Maple Ave. entered the home and began smashing windows, doors and other items — and implied to the frightened residents that he also had a gun, the Saratoga County Sheriff's Office said.

(Via Jordan Carleo-Evangelist). --Kristi

status_message: Breaking: The 22-year-old son of Rensselaer Police Chief Rick Fusco was charged with drunken driving after violent crash Wednesday morning that closed down Third Avenue extension, town police said.

BREAKING: HERKIMER, N.Y. (AP) — A man opened fire at a car wash and a barbershop a mile away Wednesday morning, killing four people and wounding at least two others, police said, and the suspect was being sought.

State police told local media outlets a man shot and killed two unidentified people Wednesday morning at Gaffey's Fast Lube in the village of Herkimer. Two others were killed at John's Barber Shop in the village of Mohawk. They said a total of six people had been shot.

-- Michael

The Tang Museum in Saratoga Springs has the first survey of her career in an exhibit that is a must see explosion of color. status_message:
The Federal Aviation Administration is investigation an outbreak of the 'Harlem Shakes' on a Frontier Airlines flight.

No, it's not some new flu. For those who haven't been near youtube lately, the 'Harlem Shakes' is a new dance with a rapidly growing series of videos.

So the Colorado College Ultimate Frisbee Team decided to make its own video in an unusual location: midflight. (We are so jealous of the ABC News headline: 'Shakes on a Plane.')

In a video that went viral, the team got all the passengers up and dancing. The airline said it was perfectly safe, as the seat belt light was off.

Watch the video here: (via Tim O'Brien). --Kristi
link_name: FAA investigates 'Harlem Shakes' dance on plane - Getting There

The teens were Keyanna Bradley, 18; and Ravenal Gregory Dunbar and Keith D. Ferguson, both 17.

Via Amy Biancolli. --Kristi

GRAFTON — Ray L. Darling Sr., Grafton town supervisor and an 11-time world-champion professional arm wrestler, died Friday night of endocarditis, said Nelson Darling, his brother.

Darling was, said those who knew him, a daunting competitor who could be ferocious in a match but always behaved with decency and friendliness afterward. He also served as ambassador for an unsung sport, bringing his knowledge and enthusiasm to far-flung corners of the globe.

Max Etienne, the city police officer charged with drunken driving after police say he sideswiped several cars on South Main Street Sunday was in court today for his arraignment.

Etienne was not on duty at the time of the crash. 

His lawyer points out that there are DWI cases in court every weekend, but this one is getting more attention because it involves an officer. 

Do you think DWI charges should be stiffer for police officers or should everyone be held to the same standards? -Kristi
Albany Police Officer Max Etienne arrives in City Court to answer charges that he was drunk when his SUV sideswiped cars parked on a city street Sunday. -- Mike G.

status_message:
It now appears there's a place among the pines for "The Place Beyond the Pines" with a special screening in Schenectady for the film shot in and around Schenectady.

On Saturday, the Times Union reported local officials' disappointment that no plans were in place for a promised premiere at Proctors this spring for the film for which hundreds of locals were cast as extras or worked in other ways.

By Monday the Daily Gazette ran a story that a premiere was indeed in the works, which was news — good news — to local officials.

"It really woke some people up," Mayor Gary McCarthy said of the Times Union story.


Read more: http://www.timesunion.com/local/article/Pines-screening-coming-4288253.php

-- Michael
link_name: 'Pines' screening coming

This job market is difficult for any individual seeking a job today. The Times Union is interested in hearing from men and women who are coming out of the military and are looking for a different career path.  How has their experience been looking for a job in the capital region? What services are being provided for veterans, if any?  How are they going about their career search and in what areas specifically are they looking for jobs?

To be considered for the story, email Caroline Murray at cmurray@timesunion.com

-Kristi

During the same interview he said that life in the country meant having to 'drive 20 miles to buy a gingham dress or a Sears, Roebuck suit.'

The Boys Scouts of America is considering a dramatic change in its controversial policy of excluding gays as leaders and youth members.

Under the change being considered, the different religious and civic groups that sponsor Scout units would be able to decide for themselves how to address the issue — either maintaining an exclusion of gays or opening up their membership.

status_message:
Would you "like" if the driver of your hearse, or your family member's hearse, went through the Burger King drivethru? --Kristi 

This gives new meaning of getting a fast food order "to go."

In honor of an 88-year-old who loved his cheap eats, mourners in Pennsylvania followed his hearse through the drive-thru of a Burger King.

And each one of them stopped to get a Whopper Jr., the favorite of David S. Kimme Jr. They got one to place on his casket too.

Yes, the  fast-food place knew they were coming and were ready to serve them.

"He always lived by his own rules," said Linda Phiel, one of Kime's three daughters, told the York Daily Record. "His version of eating healthy was the lettuce on the WHOPPER JR."
link_name: Funeral makes run through Burger King drivethru - Getting There - Covering transportation in the Cap

According to multiple trade reports, JJ Abrams, 46, is set to direct the next installment of "Star Wars," which Disney has said will be "Episode 7" and due out in 2015. Disney bought "Star Wars" maker Lucasfilm last month for $4.06 billion.

The Emmy-award-winning director of the TV show "Lost" also captained the reboot of "Star Trek" for rival studio Paramount Pictures, with the next installment in that series, "Star Trek: Into Darkness," set to hit theaters May 17.

Read more: http://www.timesunion.com/news/article/Reports-JJ-Abrams-to-direct-next-Star-Wars-4221569.php

-- Michael

status_message: If you are watching the inauguration ceremony later today, what are you looking most-forward to? Hearing Obama speak? The musical performances? The fashion? Something else? --Kristi

One person died Sunday afternoon in a head-on collision along Route 22, State Police said.

Troopers said a 2000 Plymouth Voyager veered over the road's dividing line and collided with a Lexus SUV. Three people in the SUV were taken by ambulance to Berkshire Medical Center and then airlifted to Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston, Troopers said. The driver of the Voyager was pronounced dead at the scene.

The names of the injured are being withheld, pending family notification. Troopers said the crash remains under investigation, and anyone with information should call (518) 783-3211.
link_name: Head-on crash in Stephentown kills 1

When Sandy Hook Elementary School students return to classes, it will not be in the building where 20 of their classmates and six staffers were killed in a rampage Friday.

Superintendent Janet Robinson said a temporary home for Sandy Hook students will be announced Sunday.

"We will start in a different location," Robinson said Saturday night. "We will not enter that building right now."

Sandy Hook students will resume classes Wednesday, while students at the district's other six buildings will return to school Tuesday.

status_message:
Social media is where people turn to celebrate the birth of a child or a new job. It's also the platform people gravitate toward to when they're sad, hurt and mourning.

That was the case with the Saturday night car crash on the Northway that left two Shenendehowa High School students dead, and two others injured.

It was shortly after 10 p.m. when a man police say was speeding and had been drinking rear-ended the Ford Explorer being driven by Chris Stewart, a high school senior and captain of the football team. Deanna Rivers, Matthew Hardy and Bailey Wind also were in the SUV.

By 10:30 p.m., the Tweets started. Speculation turned to truth. Truth became heartache. Hashtags like #Ibelieve and #shenstrong came first. #ShenFamily and #Shaker followed.

And then #RIPChrisandDeanna.
link_name: Social media unites the mourning

status_message:
Deanna Rivers played softball at Shenendehowa and kept score for the boys' basketball games.

Chris Stewart was a captain on the football team, a starter on the offensive and defensive lines. Matthew Hardy was his teammate.

Bailey Wind, a standout diver at Shaker, started dating Stewart shortly after Rivers introduced them after a football game last year over ice cream at Friendly's. The couple celebrated their first anniversary last week with a home-cooked dinner of Wind's favorite foods: french fries, bagels with cream cheese, and mozzarella sticks, served by Stewart over candlelight.
link_name: Shen students mourned

status_message:
State Police say the driver who caused the Northway accident that killed two Shenendehowa students Saturday night might be charged with vehicular manslaughter, after he tested positive for alcohol at the scene.

During a press conference Sunday afternoon, State Police said their investigation indicates 22-year-old Dennis Drue of Clifton Park drove his 2004 Volvo across three lanes and hit a 2004 Ford Explorer being driven by Shenendehowa senior Chris Stewart.
link_name: Police: 22-year-old driver drank alcohol before fatal crash that killed two Shen students

status_message:
Q: Why does the city of Albany seem so unconcerned with jaywalking and double-parking? Central Avenue is a nightmare, and pedestrians step out of nowhere in front of you. Another danger area is westbound on Clinton Avenue as you cross Pearl Street in front of the Palace Theatre.

There is no parking from Pearl to Chapel Street, but cars seem to be constantly stopping or parked at the curb there, obstructing the view of the crosswalk or impeding traffic. Clinton has two westbound lanes east of Pearl Street that can flow safely past the Palace if the curb is free as signs intend.

Stop the insanity. — Steve Sims, Albany
link_name: Getting There: Jaywalkers, double-parking drivers tie up Albany traffic

In all the media hullaballoo in the wake of Superstorm Sandy and the election, this little story about former President George W. Bush escaped my notice. Some people have asked where Bush has been, especially considering how public another former president (Clinton) has been during the campaign. Good morning. What do you think of the results? Can you believe Colorado and Washington states voted to legalize marijuana?
Obama wins. Romney conceding race now.
Multiple networks say Romney has called to congratulate Obama. Romney about to give speech, if you are still up you could watch it.
NBC says Obama has been re-elected president of the United States
Who's staying up for California?
MSNBC saying that if Obama takes Florida, he's got it locked up.
Think it's safe to say a win for Congressman Tonko: 69 percent of the vote with 53 of 665 districts in.
MSNBC says "The Paul Ryan effect wasn't in Wisconsin." The state is projected for Obama.
Initial numbers in for 46th state Senate race. Tkaczyk 1,229 to Amedore's 1,027 in 4 of 286 districts.
MSNBC projecting Kirsten Gillibrand the winner.
MSNBC projects Obama winning Pennsylvania.
Fox News at this point shows Obama ahead in Ohio, Florida and Virginia; Romney winning popular vote.
At the suggestion of Melissa Breneisen Mahar -- and because CNN keeps showing McCain's numbers from 2008 -- we're watching Fox News for a bit.
CNN has Romney winning Georgia, tug of war in Florida and Virginia. Are you watching?
Now that you've voted, how do you plan to follow the results? On Facebook, timesunion.com, Twitter, Yahoo!? Or will you settle in for the night in front of TV? -- Tracy

Meanwhile, in other states, people are voting on issues such as same-sex marriage (Maine, Maryland, Washington, Minnesota), physician-assisted suicide (Massachusetts), the death penalty (California) and legalized marijuana -- not "medical marijuana"; rather, recreational marijuana (Washington, Oregon and Colorado).  

http://www.timesunion.com/news/politics/article/Gay-marriage-marijuana-highlight-ballot-measures-4011132.php

status_message:
In case you lose power, National Grid provides multiple ways to receive up-to-date information on things like restoration details, safety tips, important phone numbers and more.

Sign up for National Grid state-level broadcast text* alerts by texting the word STORM to NGRID (64743). You can opt out of receiving text messages at any time by texting the word STOP to NGRID (64743).  

You can also get safety and outage information on your mobile phone via our new mobile web browser at www.nationalgrid.com. 
 
Power outages can be reported online or by calling 1-800-465-1212 in New England and 1-800-867-5222 in New York.  (via National Grid).
Area grocery stores have been crowded. What was on your pre-storm grocery list? --Kristi

The National Weather Service in Albany says the Capital Region will be having more problems with wind, rather than rain, when Hurricane Sandy hits Monday.

Meteorologist Hugh Johnson said Sunday rainfall will be significantly less than what the Capital Region experienced with Tropical Storm Irene last year. Rainfall totals are predicted to hit 1.66 inches between Monday and Tuesday. In August 2011, Irene dumped six inches of rain in the Albany area.
link_name: Capital Region to see more wind, less flooding

status_message: What are you doing to prepare for Sandy to potentially hit the Capital Region? Stocking up on food and bottled water? Buying a generator? Nothing at all? --Kristi

VOORHEESVILLE — A 6-month-old puppy had to be pulled from a deep crevice in Thacher Park on Sunday after the pooch ran from its owner and fell off a 75-foot cliff, Albany County Sheriff Craig Apple said.

The puppy, a Shiba Inu named "Shiba," was saved by rescuers who rappelled down the soft shale ledge to rescue the dog. After a two-hour search, Shiba was found curled up in a 3-foot-deep crevice. Shiba suffered a broken leg and is being treated at Latham Animal Hospital, Apple said.

Read more: http://www.timesunion.com/local/article/Puppy-saved-after-75-foot-fall-in-Thacher-Park-3971040.php#ixzz2A2XtFLqf

With a little cake, a sign and some fruits and veggies, the Times Union is celebrating this afternoon (tena): The Times Union was named New York's Newspaper of Distinction, the top award in its circulation class, at the annual banquet of th
e state Associated Press Association Wednesday night. The newspaper's staff also won 11 individual awards, including five first-place citations. The Newspaper of Distinction award came in the 45,000-to-125,000 circulation category. "Robust political coverage is at the heart of this paper, and it shows," said the judges. "The NXIVM package displayed a commitment to in-depth reporting. There were nice writing touches throughout."

Read more: http://www.timesunion.com/local/article/State-press-group-recognizes-Times-Union-3917800.php#ixzz28SQZZft9

status_message:
Some parents of East Greenbush Central School District students are upset that the district this year dropped the most important Jewish holiday from its calendar.

For at least a decade, the district has given students and staff the day off for Yom Kippur. However, according to the 2012 school calendar, the holiest day in the Jewish year, which this year falls on Wednesday, Sept. 26, is a regular school day.

Read more: http://www.timesunion.com/local/article/Some-parents-upset-about-school-district-dropping-3860309.php 

-- Michael
link_name: Some parents upset about school district dropping Jewish holiday from calendar

status_message:
At Ten Broeck Mansion, the ghost of Revolutionary War hero Gen. Abraham Ten Broeck allegedly rattles chandeliers, levitates tables and rides his horse around the house when the moon is full. Many people say they have seen the ghost of a child at the Club Grill at the Sagamore Golf Course in Bolton Landing. Several books have been written and tours based on the ghosts said to haunt Saratoga Springs.

Is your house haunted? Tell Leigh Hornbeck about it, either here or send her an email at lhornbeck@timesunion.com, and the story may be used in a future issue of the Times Union.

Apple is holding an event in San Francisco during which it is announcing a new iPhone, capable of faster data speeds and sporting a taller screen.

The iPhone 5 will go on sale next week. It will work with fourth-generation, or 4G, cellular networks, something Samsung's Galaxy S III and many other iPhone rivals already do.

Read more: http://www.timesunion.com/business/article/New-iPhone-with-taller-screen-out-next-week-3859723.php

status_message:
Get those cameras ready for a chance to win $250 to Colonie Center. We want to see what the first day of school looks like in your household. Post an image (only one per person/family) to the Times Union's Facebook wall showing us what the first day of school looks like in your home. Be sure to include a one-sentence caption, too, explaining what's happening in the shot. 
The deadline to enter is Friday, September 7 at noon. After that, images will be posted on the Times Union's Parent 2 Parent blog where readers will vote for their favorite. The winner gets the $250 gift card to Colonie Center. 
Remember, just one image per Facebook user and include that caption or your entry will be disqualified.
Happy Labor Day everyone in the Capital Region and beyond!

Is this too risque for the historic Ten Broeck Mansion?

The 213-year-old Ten Broeck Mansion evokes old-world charm and history. In fact, it is the headquarters of the Albany County Historical Association, (ACHA), that aims to preserve and exemplify the history and heritage of New York's Capital Region.

So how does the sexy, bawdy and raucous burlesque troupe Charmed and Dangerous fit in with that kind of mission?

http://blog.timesunion.com/localarts/?p=24535

-- Michael J.

What's the lifetime cost for shooting victims? 

Vivian Kornegay is the mother of a shooting victim. Her son was shot three times in 2010: "I could not believe the amount of money that it costs. I know it's costly, because he spent a night in trauma in the ER and then two nights in ICU. ... His femur bone had to be replaced." (Paul Buckowski / Times Union)

The Times Union Brendan Lyons's story says: According to a new study by New Yorkers Against Gun Violence, the lifetime cost of being shot — per victim — is about $64,000. 

Could a gun-microstamping program help curb those costs?

Read more: http://www.timesunion.com/local/article/The-other-price-of-the-bullets-3646474.php

status_message:
Legalize it?

The debate over whether New Yorkers should be able to use medical marijuana has been a perennial topic of debate in the state Capitol. Last week, the Democratic Assembly passed a bill to legalize medical marijuana. It's not expected to get through the Republican-led Senate this year. It's been that way for years.

But what many people don't know is that medical marijuana has actually been legal since 1980. Under an obscure law that was passed 32 years ago, medical marijuana was legalized for research purposes.

Read more: http://www.timesunion.com/local/article/Bureaucracy-stalls-medical-marijuana-3639647.php

-- Michael J.

SCHENECTADY — A small Hispanic church, which sits on a hill along Albany Street, was severely damaged by an electrical fire early Friday and will probably be demolished, according to city officials.

"It does appear to be a total loss," said Pastor Emiliano Lascarez through an interpreter standing outside El Faro de Dios, which is translated Lighthouse Assemblies of God. "We want to rebuild."

Read more: http://www.timesunion.com/local/article/Fire-destroys-Hispanic-church-in-Schenectady-3568987.php

status_message:
Saturday May 5, 2012, is Free Comic Book Day. 

That's right. Comic books, for free. 

Stores in the region participating include: Earth World Comics, 537 Central Ave., and Zombie Planet, 1238 Central Ave., Albany; Aquilonia Comics, 412 Fulton St., and The Goblin's Cavern, 611 2nd Ave., Troy; Electric City Comics at 1704 Van Vranken Ave., Schenectady; and Excellent Adventures Comics, 110 Milton Ave., Ballston Spa.  

Earth World's special guests include models in Black Widow and Miss Marvel costumes, and comic book artist John Hebert, who has worked on "The Punisher" "Ghost Rider" and "Phazer." 

Earth World is also asking visitors to bring books that will be shipped to U.S. soldiers in Afghanistan through Ellen Keegan's Clifton Park-based charity, Books for Troops. So far, the store has amassed about 30,000 comic books to send to the troops, but the store will accept any kind of book, said J.C. Glindmyer, owner of Earth World.  

Earth World opens at 11 a.m. Saturday, and huge crowds are expected.
link_name: Free comic book day May 5

status_message:
So far, this is my favorite quote of the week. It comes courtesy of the story attached below as Rensselaer County Judge Robert Jacon reprimanded two teenagers in a summer assault:

"What's going on up at that high school?" the judge asked Monday. "Is everybody smoking pot up there? There must be a cloud of smoke around the whole place."

The reprimands continued Tuesday when another teen pleaded guilty in the assault: ''What has occurred, Vincent, has brought a great deal of bad publicity to your school," Jacon said. "You owe them all a giant apology. They deserve better than this.''
link_name: Judge has stern words for teens in assault

status_message: The city of Troy has eliminated college credits as a requirement to be a police officer Tuesday. The police said it put up too many limitations. For comparison, Albany and Saratoga Springs police departments do not require college credits to take the civil service exam. State Police and Colonie police require 60 credits, while Schenectady police mandate 30 credits. Do you think police officers should have some college education?
link_name: Troy drops college requirement for new police officers

status_message:
Dozens of students at the University at Albany walked out of class on Wednesday to protest tuition increases and budget cuts.

The group swelled to more than 200 when it gathered in front of the school administration building to demand that President George Philip and other top administrators give back a portion of their salaries. They chanted "let us in" and "we paid for this building" when a guard initially denied them admission.

http://www.timesunion.com/local/article/UAlbany-students-protest-tuition-increases-2204197.php

status_message:
Banned Books Week is happening now, and it is important because it shines a light on books that some communities have challenged. The reasons often have to do with books that present points of view different from the mainstream. Here are some of the top challenged books compiled by the American Library Association. Have you read any of them?

And Tango Makes Three, by Peter Parnell and Justin Richardson
The Absolutely True Diary of a Part-Time Indian, by Sherman Alexie
Brave New World, by Aldous Huxley
Crank, by Ellen Hopkins
The Hunger Games, by Suzanne Collins
Lush, by Natasha Friend
What My Mother Doesn't Know, by Sonya Sones
Nickel and Dimed, by Barbara Ehrenreich
Twilight, by Stephenie Meyer
link_name: Banned Books event Thursday
